intro: Trifolium depauperatum f. franciscanum, commonly known as the Franciscan clover, is a rare and diminutive plant species belonging to the legume family, Fabaceae. It is characterized by its small, trifoliate leaves composed of three oval-shaped leaflets, often with a pale green to yellowish hue. This subspecies is native to specific regions of California, where it thrives in dry, rocky habitats. Its flowers are typically pink or white, appearing in small clusters and blooming in early spring. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in preserving its natural environment.
